I had alerted them to the sighting from the previous evening by Ray Adams and they were able to get there early enough to see two birds, while I couldn''t get out of work until 5:15. Life bird for Mike, county bird for Dave and a year bird for me.	Hunting over prairie east of 58th St. between 117th Ave. & 116th Ave. Both upper & underwing had very light buffy basses to primaries and heavy dark crescents at tips. Almost white underwing otherwise with exception of dark crescent at wrist. After dark one heard vocalizing from prairie west of 58th.

Short-eared heard making infrequent two low raspy bark-like calls, the same as in Gratiot County earlier this year. I tried to record it twice, but as soon as I stepped out to do so, it didn't call. At least 4 minutes between each call. Took me by surprise as I actually got out to scope the pond on the opposite side of the road when I first heard it. This one was very close, clearly heard.  Bird found on 120th between 57th and 62nd.

URN:CornellLabOfOrnithology:EBIRD:OBS678897446	2021-03-19 08:42:34.111265	8829	species	Short-eared Owl	Asio flammeus			1					United States	US	Michigan	US-MI	Allegan	US-MI-005	US-MI_1590	23			Allegan SGA--Farm Unit	L752711	H	42.5499821	-86.1178436	2018-11-21	17:00:00	obsr942765	S50116389	Traveling	P22	EBIRD	48	6.437		1	1		0	1	1		Short-eared Owl chase.	Spotted at 5:38 PM in flooded meadow on 116th Ave, east of 62nd Ave. Almost directly in line with the Farm Unit barn on 118th Ave that could be seen in the distance. Hunting low over field about 300 feet from where I stood at the edge of the road. It made 3 passes, all in the same line, before I lost view of it in the darkness. Very pale underneath with dark commas showing on underwing, making this owl a Male. Broad, rounded wings and short tail, eliminated Northern Harrier. Buffy areas on upper wing detectable with my bins. Too dark for me to obtain a photo of any value. A big thanks to Tim Cornish for the info on where I might find the SEOW.

URN:CornellLabOfOrnithology:EBIRD:OBS897342316	2020-04-18 20:14:33	8829	species	Short-eared Owl	Asio flammeus			1					United States	US	Michigan	US-MI	Berrien	US-MI-021		23			Weko Beach	L579697	H	41.9423188	-86.5825653	2003-11-22		obsr426379	S67409078	Historical	P62	EBIRD				1	0		0	1	1		Weather: Winds ENE 15 mph.	This owl was flying along the shoreline and was chased by crows at Weko Beach Park.  It flew out over water, last seen heading west.  About the size of a crow, it was flying fairly low over the dunes.  Its flight was meandering and moth-like.  The facial disk was fairly rounded, outlined with a thin white ruff and ear tufts were not visible.  The underside of the wing was buffy with a brown patch at the base of the primaries and primaries had brown tips.  The bird had brown streaks on top and the buffy chest had vertical brown streaks.--Similar long-eared owl has a split facial disc with two buffy crescent-shaped halves and a black vertical streak with a white border inside the eyes.  It is more grayish on top with dark streaking and barring on the chest.

URN:CornellLabOfOrnithology:EBIRD:OBS212490627	2015-03-23 09:27:34	8829	species	Short-eared Owl	Asio flammeus			3				Unknown Sex, Immature (1); Unknown Sex, Adult (2)	United States	US	Michigan	US-MI	Chippewa	US-MI-033	US-MI_3607	12			Tahquamenon Falls SP (Chippewa Co.)	L326995	H	46.6017722	-85.2040083	2013-06-27	20:00:00	obsr334888	S15282856	Incidental	P20	EBIRD				2	1		0	1	1			Three were heard for several hours. They were also all seen from of distance no greater than 20 feet for a period of roughly 2 minutes. Two adults were seen and one immature. Short ear tufts were present on all birds and were not as large as Great Horned Owl ear tufts.. Diagnostic features were overall buff to light brown coloration, dark markings around eyes, and very short tails when seen in flight. Active before sunset in a marshy area which is also diagnostic for this species. Immature was initially hard to ID by voice because the call was much more nasal sounding than the barking "cheeeck" of the adults.

Medium-sized owl with relatively long wings, medium-brown above with pale buffy patches in primaries, tail tan -- noticeably paler than back. Underparts straw-colored, slightly darker on breast, underside of wings largely whitish.

URN:CornellLabOfOrnithology:EBIRD:OBS693807967	2019-01-04 22:38:41	8829	species	Short-eared Owl	Asio flammeus			1					United States	US	Michigan	US-MI	Huron	US-MI-063	US-MI_2760	12			7684 Haist Rd Pigeon MI	L8368780	P	43.7862075	-83.2860285	2019-01-02	16:00:00	obsr205845	S51315849	Stationary	P21	EBIRD	100			2	1		0	1	1		Continuing bird at this location.My car was a little west and John Porath's was a little east of mine. I got there around 4:00 after having a difficult time figuring out where this bird had been seen. I was sitting there a bit when John pulled up and told me I was in the right place.------We waited until the sun set and it got dark and around 5:30 the owl appeared. All the reports on this birds flight is "moth-like" or "bat-like", but it is a strong acrobatic flier. It twisted and turned its body and flew along the edge of a stand of trees and it appeared as if it was weaving in and out of spaces in the woods. It would drop down after a sharp turn and land momentarily. ----It was fairly dark but you could see the outline of this bird hunting. You could see flashes of the white patches on upper wing. ----This was my birthday and I had gotten a little lost on Haist trying to find this spot. I turned around in a farm driveway near their barn and saw the Snowy I posted on an earlier report. So. On this birthday I saw AMKE, BAEA, 2 Rough-legged Hawks, NOHA, RTHA, a Snowy and a Short-eared Owl...Nice day!	Continuing bird at this spot. It appeared around 5:30. Snowing out and in the 20's. See my notes above.

A mid-sized, relatively long-tailed, slender owl showing dark wrist patch, buffy primary area, and dark (not enough light to discern “barred”) wing-tips. I would guess a female from the darker coloration of underbody, but it was close to sunset and lighting was not conducive for such a determination. Hoping this bird — if not others- strays into our 17 Dec CBC circle a few miles to the east.

URN:CornellLabOfOrnithology:EBIRD:OBS350091836	2021-03-30 18:15:02.649806	8829	species	Short-eared Owl	Asio flammeus			1					United States	US	Michigan	US-MI	Jackson	US-MI-075		23			Watkins Lake	L213224	H	42.1232335	-84.1381818	2015-10-26	11:15:00	obsr465476	S25566491	Traveling	P22	EBIRD	130	1.127		2	1		0	1	1		A rare treat to see a short-eared owl in flight over the lake and good fortune to come across the Henises, also birding here, for its identification.	First spotted and identified by R. Henise, confirmed by D. Henise. In flight, mobbed by three crows over far northeast end of lake and trees beyond. White under wings with darker tips, lightly streaked light belly, body shape consistent with short-eared owl. Distinctive flight pattern and wingbeat consistent with short-eared owl as described by R. Henise.

After coming to this spot for a few weeks now I finally had one SEOW tonight. Great looks through my scope watching the bird hunt low, and fairly close, in the NE part of the field from the parking spot on Hawkins. I also had a very nice conversation with the daughter of the land owner where I was parked (This is the parking spot on the west side of Hawkins that has gates which lead into their property). I showed her pictures of what the owls look like and we shared some wildlife stories. She is a deer hunter, who uses the property behind the gates to hunt, and said she has had some "very rude encounters" with birders in the past. She says birders are welcome but asks people to  PLEASE PARK TO THE LEFT OR RIGHT OF THE GATE and to stay behind the tree line. She does not want the deer to be able to see you or your vehicle. If you choose to park in this area you should only see a dense tree line behind you and no open field.

Ford Airport (s. Kraft Ave. access)	L888511	H	42.8763415	-85.5267137	2010-12-07	16:50:00	obsr107741	S7221269	Stationary	P21	EBIRD	60			2	1	G209131	0	1	1			SCORE. Caleb originally spotted two VERY distant birds foraging low over a field to the NE, in front of the two red barns off Thornapple River Drive. These birds were way too distant to be confirmed as Short-ears (really should be recorded as Asio sp., but eBird won't take that.) Thankfully, a Short-eared Owl popped up very close, over the closest runway to the north (only a few hundred feet from the observation area.) Smashing views. And there's more--another bird joined this one, and began chasing it! We also heard them vocalize a few times, a muffled, hoarse grunt (almost sounded like a distant, single quack of a Mallard.) Later, singletons were seen farther out over the center of the runways and to the due east of the observation area, so four is a conservative total.

URN:CornellLabOfOrnithology:EBIRD:OBS277029860	2019-07-24 07:39:57	8829	species	Short-eared Owl	Asio flammeus			1					United States	US	Michigan	US-MI	Leelanau	US-MI-089		12			South Bar Lake/Empire Beach	L1449377	P	44.8121726	-86.0675643	2014-10-19	09:00:00	obsr293918	S20277379	Traveling	P22	EBIRD	120	1.609		6	1		0	1	1				
URN:CornellLabOfOrnithology:EBIRD:OBS277014687	2019-07-24 07:39:57	8829	species	Short-eared Owl	Asio flammeus			1					United States	US	Michigan	US-MI	Leelanau	US-MI-089		12			South Bar Lake/Empire Beach	L1449377	P	44.8121726	-86.0675643	2014-10-19	09:00:00	obsr130445	S20276501	Traveling	P22	EBIRD	120	1.609		6	1		0	1	1			We had a long, though somewhat distant look at the SEOW. We were birding at the Empire Beach. We noted a bird pretty far out over the water, flying low and heading in our direction towards shore. The first thing that caught my attention was that it didn't fly like any expected water birds (gulls, terns, ducks etc). It had very floppy, deep wingbeats interspersed with glides. As it approached I noted that it was very light in color and when it turned slightly could see the fat, flat-looking head of an owl. Then it was a matter of ruling out possibilities. It was too big for Screech or Saw Whet, too light and tan-colored for Barred, too small for Great Horned. It had dark marks at the "wrist" in the wing. It landed in the dune grass or shrubs along the shore just south of the Empire Beach. We hiked down to where it made landfall but were unable to find it there. Several good birders saw it and all agreed on Short-eared Owl. Another birder also saw a SEOW a few miles south of there around that time.

URN:CornellLabOfOrnithology:EBIRD:OBS569180169	2018-02-10 13:52:42	8829	species	Short-eared Owl	Asio flammeus			6					United States	US	Michigan	US-MI	Lenawee	US-MI-091		22			Pennington/Murphy Rd, Tecumseh	L6747571	P	42.0508223	-83.9311695	2008-02-24	18:25:00	obsr218010	S42076457	Stationary	P21	EBIRD	10			2	0		0	1	1		Jeff Schultz and several other birders reported 20 Rough-legged Hawks in area	Just after 6pm I returned to Pennington just west of Murphy and found Jeff, Pat, Ed and Jerry waiting for Short-eared Owls to appear. Jeff reported that ~20 more Rough-legged Hawks were working a field just off Kehoe Rd. Would I have loved to see that! At about 6:25pm a Northern Harrier flew over us, and a few minutes later the first of (6) Short-eared Owls appeared in the field. I played the birdJam a few times to see if any would come closer, but they were content fly and chase each other yards away from us. By 6:45pm it was too dark to see any more, so I bid Jeff a good evening. Continuing birds.

First bird lifted off from the field and immediately landed in the top of a tree.  It was keeping a close eye on the hunting Harriers.  It was soon joined by a second Short eared owl and the both flew, light and buoyant, rounded heads, flat disc face.  Light colored and smaller that the harriers by comparison.  They would crisscross each other in flight then one of them landed in the tree 10 yards from me.  Wonderful looks.  I did not have my camera with me as I was being a birder instead of a photographer.

URN:CornellLabOfOrnithology:EBIRD:OBS243817740	2021-10-08 16:15:16.245997	8829	species	Short-eared Owl	Asio flammeus			1					United States	US	Michigan	US-MI	Macomb	US-MI-099		23			Galway Bird Preserve	L2707604	P	42.6589592	-82.9346323	2009-06-05	21:15:00	obsr340804	S17760902	Stationary	P21	EBIRD	10			3	0		0	1	1			I actually located a second Short Eared Owl in the wetlands behind my house in 2012 and it was discovered in the same way as the first Short Eared in 2009.  A mob of about fifteen Common Grackles and a few Red Winged Blackbirds chased a very short necked and thick headed owl up into a tree along the middle branch of the Clinton River.  In flight its wings were almost moth-like with dark wrist patches on the under-wing with alternate buff patches on the upper-wing.  I know these owls are more rare in summer but this is definitely the right ID for this bird.  It perched and gave us great looks at its yellow eyes and heavily streaked upper-breast thinning as it reached the belly.  The bird seemed absent of ear tufts.

URN:CornellLabOfOrnithology:EBIRD:OBS377198918	2021-03-30 17:43:17.024308	8829	species	Short-eared Owl	Asio flammeus			1					United States	US	Michigan	US-MI	Macomb	US-MI-099		23			Lake St. Clair Metropark (Metro Beach Metropark)	L388494	H	42.5796301	-82.8032684	2016-02-26	17:30:00	obsr333463	S27835696	Stationary	P21	EBIRD	90			1	1		0	1	1			After many attempts I finally got some good views of this bird in my spotting scope. URN:CornellLabOfOrnithology:EBIRD:OBS221780610	2021-03-19 09:15:48.328331	8829	species	Short-eared Owl	Asio flammeus			2					United States	US	Michigan	US-MI	Manistee	US-MI-101		12			Penny Park (Eastlake)	L1094676	H	44.2521465	-86.2992811	2013-12-17	12:40:00	obsr280244	S16007703	Stationary	P21	EBIRD	20			2	1		1	1	1			Turning into the park, we saw both birds in flight over the railroad tracks.  Field marks noted:  slender --body, large head, long, narrow wings, buffy patch on upperwing primaries, white underwings with black patch at base of primaries, wing beats slow.  One bird dropped into the grass, came up with a mouse and landed on a nearby post.  Its breast was heavily streaked but belly was white with no streaking; probable male.  We then noticed second bird landing in some brush about 4 feet off the ground. It was a darker bird overall, probable female, with darker breast and buffy belly, not white as in Bird #1.  Field marks also observed were yellow eyes with dark eye patches, short ear tufts visible, facial disk framed in white, legs covered in feathers.  Photos taken.

Allen at Joslin Cove, west side of Manistee Lake.  After --receiving Brian's call, we went to the east side of the lake, at Penny Park, to get a better view of the whole marsh.  We immediately located the bird sitting at the top of a big snag. Our view through the scope revealed a medium-sized owl, with short ear tufts and a rounded facial disk.  When the bird took flight, its long narrow wings and slow, deliberate wing beats were noted.  As did the 2 Short-eared Owls we reported here in December, 2013, this individual also hunted along the railroad tracks in the middle of the marsh.  Photos.

URN:CornellLabOfOrnithology:EBIRD:OBS436647053	2021-04-01 08:12:20.865562	8829	species	Short-eared Owl	Asio flammeus			1					United States	US	Michigan	US-MI	Marquette	US-MI-103					Marquette--Lower Harbor	L744251	H	46.5379598	-87.3851520	2016-10-16	17:37:00	obsr301832	S32073907	Traveling	P22	EBIRD	57	0.805		2	1	G1969145	1	1	1		 -Submitted from eBird for iOS, version 1.3.0 Build 86	Hard to overstate how awesome this was. After we were done admiring the Dunlin, Joseph Kurtz spotted this bird flying in from the southeast. It was flapping rather slowly, and had a flat face and broad wings--it took us both a while to register the fact that there was an owl flying high over our heads! It continued to fly toward the northeast, and we guessed that it might be a Short-eared. Once over land, it found a thermal and started circling. I got it in the scope at that point, and saw the wing pattern well--mostly pale, with black at the "wrist" and at the tips of the outermost primaries. Unlike a Long-eared, there was no black barring on the flight feathers past the tips of the primaries, and the body was mostly pale. I kept it in the scope until it disappeared into the clouds. Joseph has photos, which will be added soon. Incredible, serendipitous experience.

Flat face and broad wings noted immediately.  As it flew by I saw very pale, almost white underparts with some dark coloration on the upper breast, bold pale buffy primary patches on upperwings, broad black barring on tips of outer primaries, and large black "wrist" patches on the upperwings. Underwings pale with "wrist" patch reduced compared to upperwings.----Second bird was only seen from beneath, higher up and farther out over the lake. Broad, rounded wings and flat face were also noted on this bird. Underparts were majority pale, but buffier than the first bird with a bit more dark coloration on the breast. Underwings pale with broader black barring at primary tips than Long-eared.

URN:CornellLabOfOrnithology:EBIRD:OBS569186604	2018-02-10 13:32:19	8829	species	Short-eared Owl	Asio flammeus			5					United States	US	Michigan	US-MI	Monroe	US-MI-115					Pte. Mouillee SGA	L248057	H	42.0146112	-83.2001495	2008-03-13	17:00:00	obsr218010	S42077004	Traveling	P22	EBIRD	150	6.437		1	0		1	1	1		40's	As I scoped the ducks I spotted a movement out on the ice in the Bloody Run Unit and found a Short-eared Owl taking flight. A few moments later it was joined by a 2nd bird and together they began to hunt the dike along the Middle Causeway and BRU. In no time a pair of Northern Harriers appeared and soon all four birds were flying together with the owls taking turns harassing the hawks. As I watched the show through the scope three more SEO's appeared in the Vermet Unit and began chasing a nice male Harrier that also appeared. At one point I was watching (5) SEO's and (5) NH's through the scope. Unfortunately none of the birds ever wandered my way, so I was content to leave the camera holstered. I did try a couple of distance shots for posterity and even tried a few through the scope.

URN:CornellLabOfOrnithology:EBIRD:OBS137116209	2014-10-09 20:05:25	8829	species	Short-eared Owl	Asio flammeus			1					United States	US	Michigan	US-MI	Monroe	US-MI-115	US-MI_3847	22			Antenna Farm	L911917	H	42.0176881	-83.2436657	2012-01-22	17:30:00	obsr156064	S9663222	Incidental	P20	EBIRD				1	1		0	1	1				
URN:CornellLabOfOrnithology:EBIRD:OBS577370469	2018-02-19 21:44:52	8829	species	Short-eared Owl	Asio flammeus			2					United States	US	Michigan	US-MI	Monroe	US-MI-115	US-MI_3847	22			Antenna Farm	L911917	H	42.0176881	-83.2436657	2012-01-18	17:00:00	obsr218010	S42736838	Traveling	P22	EBIRD	120	4.828		1	0		0	1	1		On Wednesday evening I took a ride out to Pt. Mouillee to look for Short-eared Owls along Haagermann Rd. and the antennae farm.  The ground was free of snow, but it was cold!	I spent some time near the corner of Labo Rd. and Haagermann Rd. thinking that the owls may be roosting in the woodline next to the antennae farm.  However, I got nervous since my view of the east side of the farm near US Turnpike was obscured, so I slowly cruised in that direction.  I stopped the car next to the only tree along Haagermann, and waited 10 - 15 minutes to see if any owls would appear.  I then moved the car farther east and got out to look around. No sooner did I leave the car that a Short-eared Owl appeared near the tree!  It flew low in the twilight and disappeared over the fence and into the antennae farm.  I quickly drove back to the edge of the fenceline and hightailed it over to the fence.  There I spotted the owl sitting in the grass about 100 yds. away. It was now about 6 pm.--A second Short-eared Owl appeared moments later and the two started to tussle in flight.  I could hear the two birds barking as they flew, circled and tussled in the air.  They then settled down in the grass as the light disappeared.  Knowing that they wouldn't be getting any closer I took my frozen fingers back to the car and headed home.   Even though I got no photo opps, I thoroughly enjoyed watching birds through the binocs!

URN:CornellLabOfOrnithology:EBIRD:OBS105091062	2021-03-19 09:18:57.583074	8829	species	Short-eared Owl	Asio flammeus			3					United States	US	Michigan	US-MI	Muskegon	US-MI-121	US-MI_2144	23			Muskegon Wastewater System	L279820	H	43.2511023	-86.0375240	2011-01-07	16:15:00	obsr130801	S7388594	Traveling	P22	EBIRD	110	16.093		3	1	G217124	0	1	0		Observers: Andy Johnson, Jonathan Lautenbach, Neil Gilbert----A very cold afternoon at Muskegon Wastewater. Open water was limited--just the two bubblers (both had few birds), a small pond in the western impoundment, and one of the cells near the entrance. Very few birds overall.	Around 5:15 Jonathan spotted the first one near Laketown and Swanson. We hung around for a good forty-five minutes watching them, and made a mostly unsuccessful trek out to the far side of the model airplane field. Later, we had fantastic views after one caught a small mammal near the road and carried it to a post right next to the road. It then carried it out into a nearby field, dropped it, and flew around more, buzzing the car. It flew within twenty feet of the car two or three times!

Arose from grass north of intersection, flew in circles around our car, looking at us the whole time. Landed in the road 4 separate times within 40-50 feet of us, peering at us and looking nervously around. Clearly this behavior was directed toward us in some way, but we were not sure what it meant. Bird flew near us within 15 feet, probably the closest I've been to the species in the wild.

URN:CornellLabOfOrnithology:EBIRD:OBS135728058	2021-03-19 09:18:57.583074	8829	species	Short-eared Owl	Asio flammeus			3					United States	US	Michigan	US-MI	Muskegon	US-MI-121	US-MI_2144	23			Muskegon Wastewater System	L279820	H	43.2511023	-86.0375240	2012-01-08	13:10:00	obsr214201	S9551016	Traveling	P22	EBIRD	320	24.140		1	1		0	1	1			LIFER !!  One of best lifer sightings ever.   Saw the birds interact with northern harriers.  Saw the birds while still light getting nice field marks.  While watching in scope, saw two other owls cross into view.  Saw the combat between the harrier and owls through the scope.  Saw Owl land in a tree and momentarily perch.  Saw them go to ground (could not see them come up with any prey though).   All this just after a full huge pink / orange moon rose up.     Owls were on South west corner of intersection. ----This was fifth attempt for SE Owls.  First in 2009 at Curtis road near Frankenmuth.   Once in 2009 in Jackson County where I saw a bird that other birders called a SE but I would not count it because I did not get good field marks in the dark.  Once in 2010 at the Wastewater.  Once in 2011 with Linda at Wastewater where we saw Harriers but no SE Owls.  And then last night where all those prior visits paid off.   ----Day started at Douglas Beach Park for Black Scoters (dipped).   Then to C Park for Long Eared Owl (dipped) .  Then to South Pier at Muskegon for Purple Sandpipers (dipped).  Was feeling pretty bummed in the afternoon while doing the wasterwater circles.  Things took turn for the better with a Peregrine around 3PM.   Took a picture of a snowy owl that will not win award from the far distance but shouldn't have bothered the bird.  And finished with the super exciting SE  Owls from 530 ish to 550 or so.  Day was 14hours 13 minutes.   9 hours moving, 5 hours birding while walking or birding from car.   Was tired, good tired.

URN:CornellLabOfOrnithology:EBIRD:OBS726824114	2021-03-19 09:27:09.820357	8829	species	Short-eared Owl	Asio flammeus			1					United States	US	Michigan	US-MI	Osceola	US-MI-133		12			Osceola-Missaukee Grasslands SGA Unit 1	L3703616	H	44.1508659	-85.1381636	2019-03-19	18:45:00	obsr280244	S54032749	Traveling	P22	EBIRD	105	3.219		2	1		0	1	1		Clear skies, full moon, winds southwest at 5 mph.	We spotted this bird at approximately 8:05 p.m., at last light, flying low to the --ground, with quick, twisting turns, often described in field guides as a “moth-like flight.”  Overall impression: medium-sized owl, brown on upper parts; white/light underparts; buffy color at base of primaries on upperwings;  underwings white/buffy with a dark carpal patch and dark outer primary tips; rounded head.  In previous years, we saw 3 birds in this area and they began flight earlier than tonight’s bird.  When the Harriers quit flying for the night, the Owls would appear.

URN:CornellLabOfOrnithology:EBIRD:OBS281494686	2021-03-30 18:03:47.518477	8829	species	Short-eared Owl	Asio flammeus			13					United States	US	Michigan	US-MI	Saginaw	US-MI-145	US-MI_1644	12	USFWS_750		Shiawassee NWR--Wildlife Drive	L267398	H	43.3596344	-84.0304756	2014-11-13	08:30:00	obsr350280	S20597399	Traveling	P22	EBIRD	600	48.280		1	1		0	1	1		Weekly IWMMP survey along with non-waterbird observations.	The highlight of the day (well, there were many) was an incredible group of twelve SEOW in the roughly mile square "farm unit".  I could see eight at one time after seeing two in the Bremer Unit, and then two on the west end of the section.  The last and thirteenth was found in the Prairie field at the Bishop Rd platform at the west end of Curtis Rd.  I'm convinced this sizable number was due to heavy snow to the north and a drastic cool down with the temps, creating a 'perfect storm' for a major influx.  Four of them were buzzing me at one time, apparently perturbed with my presence.

URN:CornellLabOfOrnithology:EBIRD:OBS670339987	2021-04-01 08:06:17.676274	8829	species	Short-eared Owl	Asio flammeus			1					United States	US	Michigan	US-MI	Saginaw	US-MI-145		12			Heinge Properties	L8072907	P	43.1617960	-83.9703400	2018-10-25	08:37:00	obsr709880	S49453559	Incidental	P20	EBIRD				3	0		0	1	1		Birding was not the objective.  Hunting wild RNPH was on a private managed habitat.  Amazing to see how well these birds respond to some effort.  Hope to see what grassland species utilize the properties in the breeding season.	Medium sized owl with long wings. Was on ground and silently flushed in front of me at 10 yards.  Immediate first impressions was how contesting the mottled brown back was to the very white underside as the bird flared in front.  The wings were noticeably long in relation to the size of the body. Floppy, slow flight.  Buoyant in the air.  Black crescent feathers at wrists with slight black edge to primaries.  These marking really stood out.  Underside was white with brown streaking on breast.  The tail was so short I have no description.  It flew 100 yards and landed on the ground.  The habitat was a managed pheasant field.  R/O NOHA by lack of white rump patch, under wing coloration and short tail.  R/O RLHA by white coverts and crescent black versus black spot and short tail.  Both of these species I am very familiar with.  Due to this being an active hunt, I motioned to the bird as we continued on.  5 minutes later we stopped and I asked if they saw the bird.  They both did and I asked what their impression was.  “That hawk was all white underneath”, “those wings were really long”, “it didn’t seem like it was in a hurry leaving flopping like that”.

Flapping constantly with only intermittent short spurts of soaring, clearly unlike Northern Harrier. Largely mottled all over, with more buffy underbody than much darker overall back. URN:CornellLabOfOrnithology:EBIRD:OBS133323345	2021-03-31 03:28:19.703279	8829	species	Short-eared Owl	Asio flammeus			3					United States	US	Michigan	US-MI	Washtenaw	US-MI-161		23			Superior Twp. Roads	L284573	H	42.2922212	-83.6031482	2011-12-18	16:30:00	obsr134487	S9363457	Traveling	P22	EBIRD	60	1.609		4	1		0	1	1				
URN:CornellLabOfOrnithology:EBIRD:OBS577083655	2018-03-03 09:39:39	8829	species	Short-eared Owl	Asio flammeus			4					United States	US	Michigan	US-MI	Washtenaw	US-MI-161		23			Gottfredson Rd. at Vreeland Rd.	L1876275	P	42.2918184	-83.5644719	2011-12-10	16:00:00	obsr218010	S42713295	Traveling	P22	EBIRD	80	4.828		1	0		1	1	1		During the last week or two there have been reports of up to 6 Short-eared Owls appearing just after dusk in the vicinity of Vreeland Rd. and Gottfredson Rd. in Superior Township.  Birders have been commenting about the terrific views they'd been getting, so Robin and I took the opportunity to run out there and see for ourselves. A full eclipse this morning meant that there'd be clear skies and a full moon tonight.	Last evening the Short-eared Owls made their appearance as early as 4:20 pm, but tonight they wouldn't show until about 5:05 pm.  So, Joan and I, Janet Hug, Patricia Brandon, Amy Widenhofer and a few others waited, and freezed our toes and fingers before the first bird appeared across the field near the woods.  Moments later a second bird, then a third bird appeared on stiff wing-beats criss-crossing the field toward us.  I had magnificent views through the scope, watching as one bird flew directly toward me - I could make out its bright yellow eyes against its disk-shaped face as moved in my direction!--With the skies darkening, and it becoming increasingly more difficult to see the owls fly about, I grabbed the scope and headed back to the car where Robin was.  No sooner did we pull out and start back down Vreeland Rd. did one owl float right over Joan's head (I hope you got some photos, Joan!) and circle above our car.  I was too slow with the camera to get any overhead shots, but the bird drifted slowly ahead of the car for us to follow it.At one point it landed on a wooden post just a few feet to my left, and appeared as a dark silhouette against the yellow-red sunset.  You could make out its sharp talons against the clear sky.  If only I had my Better Beamer and flash unit!!!  Still, I managed a few quick frames before it flew up into a dead snag to my right.  I managed a few blurry pics through the dirty front windshield before it took off again down the road.

Several other people came to watch the SEOW show around 4:30pm	Actively foraging east of Gotfredson.  Really fun to watch them crane their long neck around to listen, and change direction on a dime to check out a new sound. URN:CornellLabOfOrnithology:EBIRD:OBS220561994	2018-08-05 13:15:36	8829	species	Short-eared Owl	Asio flammeus			6					United States	US	Michigan	US-MI	Washtenaw	US-MI-161		23			Vreeland Rd.	L828868	H	42.2910722	-83.5701871	2013-12-08	13:10:00	obsr156064	S15904094	Stationary	P21	EBIRD	250			1	1		0	1	1			As evening set a  Rough-legged hawk flushed two Short-eared Owls from their roost followed by a third bird.  They began to circle around and were soon joined by a fourth bird from the north.  I had not seen where this bird came from.  One of the four split off from the others and headed to the south and soon landed on the ground where it stayed put.  With my binoculars I started a scan of the sky from left to right and counted 2 pairs approx. 50 yards from each other and a lone bird farther to the north.  All of them Short-eared Owls.  The birds began to disperse to surrounding fields soon after I did the scan and later the short-eared owl that had landed took off again.  I have a few photos on Birding Michigan on Facebook.

Decided to visit Vreeland...No binocs, and wrote my list on our lunch receipt! Decided, luckily to holdout for the Short-eared Owl and got to see them!	Continuing birds. There were about 15 cars lined up along Gotfredson near Vreeland this evening. We got to see the Harriers just as it was getting dark...Most folks left and I turned my car around and was driving north . Just at the yellow sign that indicated Vreeland road up ahead I spotted two large birds flying. I slammed on the brakes and stood on the door jam outside of the car and watched. They were just above the telephone wires flying in the described "mothlike" fashion...Bat-like. They were together but some distance apart. The pale underside of their wings catching what light was left gave their wings a silvery shimmer. Not the best look, but you take what your given with owls! This was just after 6:00pm...Maybe 6:05.

I watched constantly from 5:45PM onward and I'm pretty confident that this bird wasn't flying around more than a minute or so before 6:29PM.  It was hunting over the field in the SW corner of the Vreeland & Gotfredson Rd. intersection.  In this field it was about 2/3 mile south of Vreeland and about 1/4 mile west of Gotfredson Rd.  I was able to observe the bird's "mothy" flight and watched it dive a couple of times into the weeds and grass, probably attempting to catch prey.  Flight style, shape, and coloration distinctive.  Much experience with this species elsewhere.

URN:CornellLabOfOrnithology:EBIRD:OBS821237652	2021-03-19 09:34:35.430448	8829	species	Short-eared Owl	Asio flammeus			1					United States	US	Michigan	US-MI	Washtenaw	US-MI-161		23			Water Conservation Easement (Vreeland Rd & Prospect Rd)	L894219	H	42.2916436	-83.6072981	2019-10-26	10:21:00	obsr1124816	S60955404	Stationary	P21	EBIRD	31			7	1	G4617062	0	1	1			Surprising!! We had just stopped at the side of the rd and it flew around 100 m high from one side of the field to beyond the fores reserve on the other side of the road. Very distinctive bird well seen by all. Distinctive moth-like wing beats that were deep and slow, slight crook at the hand joint. Broad wings with buffy underwing coverts, distinct brown bar at the base of the primaries. Primaries barred. Dark streaky chest contrasting with buffy belly (unlike leow). Completely flat face with diagnostic white face crescents. In contrast to nearby noha much bulkier build. No photographs.
